Dr. Jack Greene, Professor of
History at Hopkins, was named
last week as one of eight participants on an advisory committee to
the Maryland Educational Television Commission.

twenty to thirty half-hour programs concerned with Maryland
history. Dr. Greene stated that the
programs will be centered around
the topic of "opportunity and aspirations throughout history."
One such topic which Greene
suggested will be the Catholic and
Protestant split in the Sixteenth
Century and its effects on what
was then Maryland. Dr. Greene is
especially interested in this period
of history

example, the large numbers of vocal Negros within Maryland and
their effect on the future progress
of,the state.

polarities within Maryland will be a

special concern. Effects of the economic struggle between trends towards the internationalization of

long-range national effects.

The Students' Rights
This shall be our premise: that the University is made of three
parts - the administration, the faculty, and the students. Each of
these segments of one community has rights and powers within its
sphere.
We submit that the students, both graduate and undergraduate,
have been denied many rights in this community. Policy changes affecting them have been made without consultation. Rules have been
instituted with a disregard to a third of the society. Privilege and
humiliation are tolerated in a supposed liberal democratic institution.
Continuing further, we submit that students have the right to act
against these grievances by asserting themselves as the third and equal
part of the University troika.

Autumn Leaves

obscenely nude in a death warm sunlight, and visions flash.
We are given over to thinking of hot chocolate thoughts and the
promise of spring love. Some portents have arrived early, the body

Toward this end, and with any and all means, we do not ask, but
demand, recognition of a list of student rights. This list, signed by representatives of the administration and faculty along with the students, would put in concrete terms the relationship of the students
toward the faculty and the administration.
The Student Council has moved to draw up a student bill of
rights. We hope that its efforts will be successful, and that its product will be accepted by the administration.
The American Association of University Professors has endorsed
the student rights of several universities, and we hope that such
agreement and acceptance will be forthcoming from the Hopkins administration. If Homewood proves stodgy and unmoving in entering
into dialogue on this point, it may well prove to be a grevious mistake on their part.
A student bill of rights would cover all fields of university activity,
including academic, social, and policy-making aspects.
In the academic realm students should be given a voice on faculty
committees that decide choice of courses. Students should have an
appeal on grades. Students should have a voice on the Bookstore
Committee.
In respect to the social side of university life, students should
have power to eradicate or create rules governing campus behavior.
Students should have an active voice in the policy of the Plant Manager's Office. In this area, more than anywhere else, the student
should follow rules that have been instituted by himself or his peers.
The most important area of students' rights would be in policymaking. There should be student representation on the Long Range
Planning Committee, on the Academic Council, and on the Budget
Committee. In this way policies could be developed and instituted
that would serve the interest of the faculty, the administration, and
the students. The institution of the new drop date was sprung as a
surprise on the student body,the group most affected by the change.
By having students on the policy-making level this kind of the unpleasant trick could be avoided.
There should also be a list of general student rights such as no administration reprisal for demonstrations, automatic review for all suspensions and dismissals, and a long term acceptance of the bill of
rights itself.
A student bill of rights should also command the respect and adherance of the students. It would not be a mandate for unreasonable
actions, but insurance against administration tyranny. It would not
be anarchy, but democracy. It would not lead to chaos, but would
alleviate frustration. It would finally bring the students into an equal
partnership with the rest of the community, allowing graduate and
undergraduates to control their environment to a greater degree. It
would improve the University so that future students could be the
beneficiaries of a new, truly free educational institution.
We await anxiously the administration reply.

The "Mothers of Invention" are more complex
than the cultural trend into which they fit. Classification of their music is impossible. It is so multifaceted that it overlaps the purely psychedelic or
the purely satirical. Their previous records and performances have been composed of "chance music"
and comments on the Great Society. Under the
technological direction of Frank Zappa,(composer
and arranger) they are moving toward a pure expression of electronic music.
This movement eliminates the negative note in
their reaction towards the "middle class America"
and builds toward the positive climax of a serious
musical trend. Electronics is a field of its own.
Basically, it involves the extraction of different
tones from a pure sound. The "Mothers" first
principle is that the natural voice or one natural
note can be amplified, interrupted or changed to
produce different tonal qualities. This technique is
accomplished through the use of devices such as
the ring modulator, oscillator and music snythesizer which receive the standard note or chord and
remove the naturalness of the sound. Through adjustment of various pitches two or more sounds
from the original one are produced.

produce. Their seriousness as artists cannot be denied. Taken as a whole, the group lives within the
media they use for communication. There is no
aura of pretentiousness surrounding any member

The "Mothers of Invention" are more complex
than the cultural trend into which they fit. Classification of their music is impossible. It is so multifaceted that it overlaps the purely psychedelic or
the purely satirical. Their previous records and performances have been composed of "chance music"
and comments on the Great Society. Under the
technological direction of Frank Zappa,(composer
and arranger) they are moving toward a pure expression of electronic music.
This movement eliminates the negative note in
their reaction towards the "middle class America"
and builds toward the positive climax of a serious
musical trend. Electronics is a field of its own.
Basically, it involves the extraction of different
tones from a pure sound. The "Mothers" first
principle is that the natural voice or one natural
note can be amplified, interrupted or changed to
produce different tonal qualities. This technique is
accomplished through the use of devices such as
the ring modulator, oscillator and music snythesizer which receive the standard note or chord and
remove the naturalness of the sound. Through adjustment of various pitches two or more sounds
from the original one are produced.

produce. Their seriousness as artists cannot be denied. Taken as a whole, the group lives within the
media they use for communication. There is no
aura of pretentiousness surrounding any member
of the band - - they are as honest in their appearance as in what they say.
In the expression of their attitudes they have
aroused a fear for the unknown, one of the greatest threats to conservative society.

they are trying to do. Their music demands a receptive and creative audience. An audience that
